body:
I cherry-picked that last cleanup commit (which did touch several of the exact files in `fuseki1` that are giving me a pain) but I'm still getting:

```
org.apache.jena.fuseki.TestSPARQLProtocol  Time elapsed: 0.125 sec  <<< ERROR!
org.apache.jena.atlas.web.HttpException: java.net.SocketException: Connection reset
    at org.apache.jena.fuseki.TestSPARQLProtocol.beforeClass(TestSPARQLProtocol.java:42)
Caused by: java.net.SocketException: Connection reset
    at org.apache.jena.fuseki.TestSPARQLProtocol.beforeClass(TestSPARQLProtocol.java:42)

org.apache.jena.fuseki.TestQuery  Time elapsed: 0.113 sec  <<< ERROR!
org.apache.jena.atlas.web.HttpException: java.net.SocketException: Connection reset
    at org.apache.jena.fuseki.TestQuery.beforeClass(TestQuery.java:51)
Caused by: java.net.SocketException: Connection reset
    at org.apache.jena.fuseki.TestQuery.beforeClass(TestQuery.java:51)
```

even without the calls to `resetServer()`. Looking further...

http_op_3 branch should be good now : ServerCtl moved to fuseki1 and used uniformly.  After this is finished, it coudl be cleaned up or more reasonably, extract that code, add the capabilities to jena-fuseki2-embedded and change jena-jdbc-driver-remote accordingly (just imports by that stage?).

Several commits.

If ti works to merge from that branch, they'll be more "git checking" everything is pulled in.

_O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!_

Full green light build. Thanks enormously for this help, @afs. I'm still very much a beginner with the various form of test machinery in the codebase. After we merge this, I'll file a ticket for polishing the new `ServerCtl` and "factoring it across" to `fuseki2-embedded`.

So I still owe @rvesse good examples of complex authN setups, but that is a task for documentation. I don't think we have anything left on this ticket/PR-- I think it can stop blocking release!
@ajs6f  What's the next step?
For my money, we can merge this. I think we might want to keep JENA-576 open until @rvesse is happy with the new documentation.

I don't know what state the PR is in.  I don't see the changes I made today to sort things out on the PR so I am unclear what "it" is and what your happy comment refers to.

I can merge it,or you can, as-is together with http_op_3 commit 944e520 and then resolve JENA-576 so it is recorded for this release.

The state is that it builds and passes all tests. The dependency is upgraded and the use of the deprecated API from HTTP Commons is removed (at least all that I could find). I now see that I didn't push the last commit I cherry-picked-- sorry!

That `http_op_3` commit https://github.com/apache/jena/commit/944e5208ff0fbb4e87fcab7417b760252d9aabfc did come over into this PR as commit https://github.com/apache/jena/pull/151/commits/722b3f371abf5d31ce1f1564da134a7a76f03ca0.
I'm fine if you would merge this and f you'd like to close 576 for the release. I will work on the docs separately.

This is the first part of reorganizing the test server. Changes are made to Fuseki1, and to jena-jdbc-driver-remote, which uses a Fuseki1 server for its testing.

The changes for jena-jdbc-driver-remote mean it should just be a change of dependency to switch to using Fuseki2.

This PR is not yet complete - it shows how the test setup work for Fuseki1. The same changes will be made to Fuseki2, then switch jena-jdbc-driver-remote.

Commit 7c3a5cf applies the test sever style to Fuseki2. It also makes naming consistent across Fuseki1 and Fuseki2.  

This completes this PR.

jena-jdbc-driver-remote has not been switched to using Fuseki2. Setting up a complete background test server outside the Fuseki2 development file tree would need some work. Instead, using the embedded Fuseki2 server would be a good test of usage of an embedded server.

`AbstractFusekiTest` -- it isn't so simple though as there is only one super class and it ends up competing for that. And the Auth tests need to be different again.

So this PR is just Fuseki1, Fuseki2 and applied to our own code. Each Fuseki has its own needs.  jena-jdbc-drive-remote is the one instance of something using a Fuseki as a test server while not testing Fuseki.  When I realized that, it became clear why the idea of only one framework for both uses was proving a bit messy.

A framework to use Fuseki for testing use of SPARQL protocols can go in the embedded server (= no file footprint).

Testing Fuseki2 does need the full server, file footprint and all.
(Wrong button again)
(rebased to Apache master branch)

Looks good to me

My only concern is how Shiro behaves in a environment where each invaded server may have a different security configuration.

Embedded Fuseki does not use Shiro.

Fuseki (full) uses Shiro setup via the servlet context (not that Fuseki)full is aimed at multiple servers per JVM: better either 2 ports, one server, one JVM or multiple servers, multiple JVMs.
I think I addressed the comments given here in that last commit.
Glad to!
@Claudenw are you okay with this PR now?
@Claudenw If you have no further objection, I'm going to merge this EOD today.
@Claudenw @afs Hang on-- I just reread that @afs would like this to hold until post-3.1.1, so I won't merge it after all.
Given the delay due to sorting out HttpOp etc, it can go in from my POV.
Oh, cool. Okay, back to "will merge EOD today unless @Claudenw objects".
Invalid - it has picked up changes from another branch.

That looks OK for one file.  What to do about multiple files on the command line is trickier - that is, there are reasonable use cases for different behaviors.

The call stack is (deepest first):

```
parseRIOT(String, String, TypedInputStream) : void - riotcmd.CmdLangParse
parseFile(String, String, TypedInputStream) : void - riotcmd.CmdLangParse
parseFile(String) : void - riotcmd.CmdLangParse
exec$() : void - riotcmd.CmdLangParse
exec() : void - riotcmd.CmdLangParse
```

where the multiple file loop is in `exec$()`. I wonder if the "parse*" ought to return true/false (or throw a custom exception) as to whether they succeeded or not and the decision of whether and when to exit is made in `exec$` (just before the `postParse` step). Then an attempt to parse all the files happens and then `exit(1)` if any are broken.

I'm a little mistrustful of a boolean return value there because of an problem @osma dealt with recently wherein he wanted a parse to sort-of succeed but drop bad tuples. Maybe we could return there a marker  `interface ParseCompletion {}` (better name needed) and an out-of-the-box `enum StandardCompletion implements ParseCompletion {SUCCEEDED, FAILED}`? I know that's more complex, but not hugely so and it would bake in some room for expansion or extension.

The parser has already thrown RiotException by the time this PR comes into play. boolean is to note there is "exit(1)" and not "exit(1)" states.   Boolean, enums or exception are all 2-state returns for that condition; exception and message output or not. This is all within the single class of the command itself

Dropping bad triples needs parser changes. It is a much wider change.

Indeed, there is an argument not to design to a future feature until that feature is fully described!

Well, the `enum` is just a convenience. It's the `interface` that matters, and the new condition is that parsing completed but tuples were dropped. `exit(n)`? But I admit that I don't understand all of what @osma would want anyway.
As long as that `n` is not a count! Exit codes are "enums", not a sneaky way to return a variable result.

Oh, goodness no-- I just used `n` because I'm imagining a series of exit codes (e.g. 0 = success, 3 = partial success (tuples dropped for bad URIs, see STDERR for details), 4 = partial success (tuples dropped for bad syntax, see STDERR for details), etc.) None of which do I have actually planned or am I ready to write, so I guess I'm done talking. :)

This usage is calling into the middle of internal code.

Fixing output code seems wrong. It is better to initialize as objects get created, not on output. This shows the root cause is somewhere else.

Except for `impl` packages and suffixes it is never easy for Jena users to know what is "internal code". 

If it's in [Javadoc](https://jena.apache.org/documentation/javadoc/arq/org/apache/jena/riot/out/NodeFmtLib.html), and it is useful "outside" without much hazzle, then I don't see why it should be called "internal" just because it is also used internally.

Agree that it would be good to ensure Jena initialization from `NodeFactory`.

The root cause:

Commit 204f253 switched Context to using a `ConcurrentHashMap`, commit d67a426 added a check for null otherwise nothing has changed since 3.1.0.

The better fix is to initialize in `NodeFactory` (and `Node` for legacy reasons) only. I have tested this in a build.

There is little point in a specific test because tests run in the overall suite; it's almost confusing to have a test that doesn't. With initialization in `NodeFactory` this will get tested anyway!

Also, it would help to unroll ARQConstants (for RDF, RDFS, OWL, XSD) so it does not need JenaSystem.init and then it is, with care, init-safe.

See PR#192 for that all made real.

The original example works when run separately to ensure minimal system initialization.

Yes, your pull request looks like the best approach.

Suggestion: we merge this as is, write a proposal on JENA-1197 that each call of a single file parse returns an object describing the outcome and `exec$()` aggregates the results into a final outcome, including setting the exit code.

> Suggestion: we merge this as is, write a proposal on JENA-1197 that each call of a single file parse returns an object describing the outcome and exec$() aggregates the results into a final outcome, including setting the exit code.

Yup, agree. Here's the output when running a command with one valid file, followed by invalid files.

```
$ riot --validate /tmp/valid.ttl /tmp/invalid1.ttl /tmp/invalid2.ttl

INFO  File: /tmp/valid.ttl
INFO  File: /tmp/invalid1.ttl
ERROR [line: 1, col: 4 ] Unrecognized: FDS
```

The valid file is a cheeses ttl file found in Jena sources. The invalid file has some random data.

```
cat /tmp/invalid.ttl 
fdsfd
```

Maybe we could merge and fix JENA-1197, then file a new issue to accommodate the more complete changes suggested in this pull request.
I can confirm that this patch solves the issue related to 303 redirects, outlined in JENA-1263.
And some clearing up / simplifying.

@ajs6f This affects TIM.  I tested and TIM is term based but it's use of GraphView claims it handled literal datatyping.

(Ah - I see you beat me to it!)

@afs Hm. [GraphInMemory](https://github.com/apache/jena/blob/master/jena-arq/src/main/java/org/apache/jena/sparql/core/mem/GraphInMemory.java) doesn't override for its own capabilities. Sounds like it should have been doing that, but now this change solves that problem (because of [this](https://github.com/apache/jena/pull/196/files#diff-d154f363df7630907dac5f0ba5d539a8R218)), right?

Yes - this makes overriding unnecessary. The second commit on this PR takes it out of GraphTDB for the same reason.

Ideally, maybe, GraphBase should provide a safer set (no iterator remove, no value indexing) and GraphMem / GraphMemBase add the specific capabilities.

Then the InfGraphs are probably inconsistent as their capabilities partially rely on their base graph.

More evidence Capabilities are not used for real.

The "test" module is needed because the tests need a Fuseki test server but  jena-rdfconnection is before Fuseki in the build sequence.

Some tests in jena-fuseki-core that are DatasetAccess and query, update SPARQL API calls could similarly be moved to this new location.

This is contributed as a new maven module - the best place to put it is for discussion.

It introduces no new 3rd party dependencies.
Documentation draft: https://github.com/afs/jena/blob/rdf-connection/jena-rdfconnection/Documentation.md
Is the basic idea of `jena-integration-tests` to provide a place for inter-module tests?
Thank you for the reviews - typos corrected.

> Is the basic idea of jena-integration-tests to provide a place for inter-module tests?

The driver is that testing remote operations needs a SPARQL server but that is not a dependency of the code, only of the tests.  However, Fuseki isn't built at this point in the build process.

jena-rdfconnection goes into the apache-jena-libs and apache-jena artifacts but Fuseki is built after those.

This must be a common need in system so if there is a better common pattern, then I'm happy to switch to that.

There are a number of ways this could be done:

1. Build modules in a different order - e.g. do building steps before delivery modules.
2. Put the tests in Fuseki
3. As here, a specific module.
4. Use a previous version of Fuseki.

(1) works in this case but it may not work out whereas the idea of an integration testing module, seems general. (2) is a less clean version of (1); this is already done in a small way - those can be moved now. (4) seems accident prone.

So (3) looks the best way and may be applicable for other situations. It may even to help unblock evolution of the legacy module/packing structure (the old Turtle reader in jena-core is needed for assembler tests - I haven't had a chance to try yet).

I wasn't happy with a single fixed way to use a local connection - I think all of copy (pseudo remote), no isolation and read-only (no copy so a pragmatic balance for larger datasets) make sense in different situations.

so I have added two isolation modes added to the documentation and added tests.

I am completely cool with the idea of separate i-test modules-- I think that's very much the right idea. Is the thinking that we can move it later in the build as need be (i.e. if we wanted to include some i-tests for some later modules)?
Its location in the build shouldn't matter too much, just after all the modules it is testing.
Right, cool. Just wanted to make sure we leave the door open to move it later in the build to include testing of later modules. +1

Just replacing some homegrown stuff with library functions that came out since, and pruning two classes, one for which an equivalent is now available in library code, and the other wasn't used at all and never has been AFAICT.
Commits are orthogonal. I'll wait until the middle of the week in case anyone has any comments/objections.
Also will send a further commit getting rid of calls to now-deprecated functions.
@afs , yep there's another commit coming getting rid of those warnings. Just an oversight on my part, sorry.

All I could find re: 803804 and 858163 was [this](https://osdir.com/ml/misc.ontology.protege.owl/2004-04/msg00904.html). Something to do with the old, old confusion between XML Namespaces and RDF prefix management and numerical localnames?

It seems to be something to do with how `find` behaves if called multiple times with the same arguments as needed by pretty printing in XML. Turtle does not perform an equivalent test.  I don't recall that warning message ever being mentioned on users@ so I'm tempted to assume it is no longer relevant.

Thanks, I got caught up with holiday stuff and forgot to merge this.
Hi! Sorry, I had been busy. I'll take a look at the warnings and possibly create a PR in the coming days.

The key point is that warnings are in user code.

If the consequences are large numbers of warnings, we will have created a support problem when in fact the user code works perfectly well.

One problem is that "try-with-resources blocks are in general unnecessary when using non-I/O-based forms", and there is no distinction in Jena's type system between `Model`s that are disk-based and those that aren't (and I'm not saying there should be).
I will back out the mods to autogen code-- certainly there's no point in tweaking that. I'm still very much learning what is and isn't autogen in ARQ and how it all works.

The auto-generated code has auto-generated comments to that effect at the top :-) ... which Eclipse then goes and hides :-(.

RAT seems to have some built-in detection code because these files don't trigger a validation failure.
Autogen code is now back where it started.
This is good stuff-- thanks for taking a problem and turning it into an improvement!

@ajs6f thanks for the review. I made most (all ?) of the changes that you suggested. Remains the problem "loading remote context failed: http://schema.org/" - unrelated to this PR per se.

Regarding the section that you find too complex: I'd be happy to learn about a better way to read data from an InputStream, that supports the passing of a Context

@fpservant Oh my goodness, you are quite right. There is no appropriate method in `RdfDataMgr`! @afs I think we could reasonably add such a method as part of this PR-- it would clearly be useful. What say ye?
With the changes that have happened, I'm not seeing the comment to which you refer.
@fpservant @afs Yes, exactly. Having a method on `RdfDataMgr` that takes `InputStream` _and_ `Context` seems very natural.

What about a `parse` method?

As discussed before, adding a lot extra functions just for one particular case of one particular language, seems to create unclarity for the general usage.  The read(...URL, Context) cases were added after discussion last time.

Local contents and overriding remote JSON-LD context does not seem to me to be a common need because you can change the local contents.  Test cases often do things that are not common.

(`RDFDataMgr.createReader` is there to expose specifics as well and is in the same style of old Jena readers.)

You're saying use `org.apache.jena.riot.RDFDataMgr.parse(StreamRDF, InputStream, String, Lang, Context)`? That does make sense. I guess I was thinking of the general need to customize parsing behavior, but as long as there is a reasonably concise form, that's all I care about. @fpservant does that work for you?
@afs  Are you cool with this now?

This looks nice now.  Please do either file a ticket for the new bug you found or find a ticket that already describes it (if there is one) and reference it in the comment you left in the test case with a `TODO`. That will help me remember to try to fix it! (Unless you want to do that too. :) )

@ajs6f are you speaking of the "org.apache.jena.riot.RiotException: loading remote context failed" thing? 

1) note that in the context of a test, jena doesn't want to depend on a connexion to the network (so told me @afs when I was working on JSON-LD writing - and getting, BTW, same kind of problem, for reasons which are supposed to have been solved since). So the catch Exception must probably stay in the code of the test.

2) I'd be curious to know whether someone else, who is completely sure about its settings, also gets this problem (problems with http connexions may be many different things!) (Other people experiment it, cf. question on jena-users that initiated this PR, but are they up-to-date?). So I would be happy to get confirmation of the problem from others.

I tried to track it down. It occurs to me at ```com.github.jsonldjava.core.DocumentLoader.loadDocument(String)``` line 29

where I get:
```org.apache.http.ConnectionClosedException: Premature end of Content-Length delimited message body (expected: 124346; received: 0```

@fpservant Yep, that's what I meant. I would be looking that as solvable by moving the location of the schema to a resource supported on the testing box, so it's not being resolved from the network. Note I'm not asking you to do that, just to make a note that someone should.

For unit tests you can use a JAR-cached context by using the [jarcache.json](https://github.com/jsonld-java/jsonld-java#loading-contexts-from-classpathjar) approach and put it together with the JSON schema file in `src/test/resources/` - that would override the specified URL.

A similar approach can be used with `src/main/resources` - but then of course you would have to keep the schema cache up to date, so that's more for the end application to do to avoid external network dependencies.

Note that the actual [schema.org context file](http://schema.org/docs/jsonldcontext.json) is [licensed as CC BY SA](http://schema.org/docs/terms.html), but you could make a minimal version made just for the test which would not infringe copyright.

External linkages in the tests are, in the long term, not good. At some point, the remote resource will be uncontactable. Sometimes people need to run the test offline as well.

For the long term robustness of the tests suite, I think the level of need for an external resource needs to be quite high. At least make the test respond to different errors - uncontactable vs a failure with the expected actions after the content is fetched. Doing that is really quite hard - and the remote contents may change.

(this is what `StreamManager` is good for).
@afs I think the point that @stain and I are making is that there is no need for an external resource linkage at all.

If this is the beginning of "jena-ldp", do we want a package under src/main?

`pergraph`: Just thought that `core` was getting awfully crowded. I don't care one way or the other-- happy to put them anywhere.

`jena-ldp`: One of the questions I'm trying to raise with this PR is exactly that-- is this useful only for LDP-type workloads (in which case maybe it belongs outside ARQ entirely) or not (in which case it has more claim to be in ARQ)?

could introduce more finely-grained locking for datasets, and I =
definitely think of this as a first tiny baby step in that direction.
